Wellington Management.pros: Decent Pay, Consistent Raises, Great Training, At the time had a great DEI program. Also if you are interested in developing out of the role the firm is very supportive. Their current CEO started at the firm as an admin.
Wellington Management.cons: I'd say most cons are more role related than firm related

Wellington Management.pros: good benefits, good opportunities to learn about an asset manager with a broad array of products, employees are generally smart and know a lot about financial markets. Some of the people that work here are genuinely great people.
Wellington Management.cons:
The management decisions that the company makes are poorly thought out and are seemingly driven by a fear of being tossed aside during the next round of layoffs if "productivity goals" are not met. This manifests itself in petty politics and a facade of superficiality that drives the culture. Layoffs have resulted in a number of teams being understaffed and poorly managed and has led to a steadily declining morale among workers who have to handle workloads that are vastly greater than their pay-grade warrants. Employees who are not making six-figures are regularly worked 50-60 hour weeks. These time expenditures are both known of and under-appreciated by management and there have been no efforts to increase hiring to more evenly distribute workloads. It starts off feeling like a great place to work because the free coffee bar and snacks do miracles for propagandizing the quality of the culture, but after a few months it will become abundantly evident where there are pretty serious lapses in how things are run. Outside of culture, the data systems are all over the place and the amount of incongruities that exist in them is astonishing for a $1T+ firm.

Bluntly, everyone has their head up their own a-- and efforts to engage in meaningful dialogue or develop a deeper understanding of your role are often met with the attitude that you are being nuisance for attempting to learn and do your job. You are able to learn a fair amount, but primarily through independent work, and you have to be prepared to regularly feel like you are resented by your coworkers for having to perform the tasks that are necessitated by your job. 

One gets the sense of there being a vague, frenetic neurosis that dictates day-to-day workflow even when things aren't that busy and that a very real and ominous discontent often permeates throughout the office.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: At what point does management feel that profit margins cease to supersede the welling-being and happiness of its employees? If you are running a company and increase your profit margin by 1-2% over the course of a year, but all of your employees hate their lives and are overworked, what actually is the point of your business model?

Wellington Management.pros:
401k
Respected name on your resume
Wellington Management.cons: It’s not a meritocracy and your contributions will not significantly impact career progression. Instead advancing relies on randomly being in the right division or identity. High performers will be frustrated. The firm lost its edge and is struggling to find a new culture. Clients and results are no longer the focus, internal politics and chasing high fee products are management’s priorities.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: Reward performance across all functions and remove the dead weight. Partners should be the hardest working employees and set the example but many are coasting.

Wellington Management.summary: A Demoralizing Workplace Where Merit Takes a Back Seat to Politics
Wellington Management.pros:
Strong 401(k) and profit-sharing program
Good health insurance and overall benefits package
You’ll likely find one or two genuinely wonderful colleagues who make the experience more bearable
Wellington Management.cons:
Toxic Work Culture: The environment is characterized by clawing at one another for survival, where advancement beyond the early-career stage often seems to require undermining colleagues rather than being recognized for merit. On multiple occasions, I was informally recruited for internal opportunities only to learn later that my own director actively sabotaged them—including one instance in which a hiring manager’s assistant disclosed that my director threatened to end their friendship with the hiring manager if they “stole me” from my team.

Undisclosed Layoffs: Although the firm conducted two official RIFs during my six-year tenure, it also carried out an additional several rounds of unreported layoffs across several days. Employees affected were instructed not to disclose that they had been terminated, ostensibly to avoid publicizing the actions or triggering WARN reporting requirements.

Lack of Meaningful Professional Development: Unless you happen to have an exceptional manager, “professional development” generally amounts to being assigned to projects unrelated to your role, expected to work extensive overtime with minimal guidance, and then watching managers or directors claim full credit for the results. Requests to participate in formal development programs or obtain certifications typically require exhaustive business justifications, only to be delayed for months and ultimately denied with vague statements that “it’s not the right time.”

Out-of-Touch Leadership and CEO: During a panel discussion on career advancement, the CEO cited access to amazing nannies and domestic help as a key factor for succeeding in their career - an especially tone-deaf message given that many non-investment employees earn under $120k and could not reasonably afford such resources. Partners aren't much better, and will often complaining to their reports about out of touch issues (ex: a partner once complained to me he paid 3x my total salary in taxes and waited for sympathy). Also noting that despite Glassdoor listing Brendan Swords as the CEO, he left the firm years ago.

Performative Niceness: While many employees appear outwardly friendly, the underlying culture is intensely gossipy and often hostile. It is common to hear disparaging or inaccurate remarks about oneself from people you barely interact with, which seems tied to the broader atmosphere of insecurity and survivalism.

Unaccountable Middle Management: Middle management operates with very little behavioral oversight, creating an environment where condescension and unprofessional conduct often go unchecked. Many managers routinely project their own stress and frustrations onto the people they supervise, leading to a climate where employees absorb emotional fallout rather than receiving support or direction. This lack of accountability not only damages morale but also reinforces a hierarchy where poor managerial behavior is normalized.

Inconsistent Return-to-Office Policies: The firm introduced a formal process for requesting exemptions from the four-day-per-week in-office policy, requiring employees to undergo an onerous approval process. Only months later, leadership abruptly reversed course and announced these exemptions would no longer be honored, leaving employees scrambling to adjust their personal and family arrangements. If you are friends with a MD or Partner, however, you can get away with showing up rarely. 

Gendered Expectations for Women: As a woman, it became increasingly clear that success was often tied less to competence and more to conforming to a narrow and problematic standard. Women who were white, conventionally attractive, and willing to engage in permissive or overly accommodating behavior advanced quickly, while those who were BIPOC or who simply delivered strong work without performing this “persona” were overlooked or sidelined. This dynamic not only created an exclusionary environment but also reinforced inequitable norms that undermined genuine merit.

Mass Exodus: Over the past year, the rapid deterioration of the culture has driven many employees to leave, with many roles left unfilled. Those who remain are stretched thin, demoralized, and often staying only in hopes of a future severance package or to bridge the gap to retirement.

Wellington Management.summary: Pretty great place, but not perfect
Wellington Management.pros: great collaborative culture, nice office, gives employees 4 remote weeks a year, low-ego culture, people stay for a really long time.
Wellington Management.cons: Most hiring decisions (as in what roles to hire for) seem to come from nowhere, rather than what the team actually needs, favoritism on Investment platform,
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: Reduce bureaucracy

Wellington Management.pros: Work life balance - you can expect a great work life balance here once you get a hang of it
Wellington Management.cons:
Everything else:
1. Job security - a lack of transparency from the Leadership team tends to surprise many people when they decide to lay people off
2. Growth - stagnant as you won't get any comps increases for years, even if you get title/officership promotions
3. Working environment - too many ordinary coworkers here, which does not matter normally but imagine when you see the ordinary ones get promoted (you know they are ordinary because they can't do things unless turning to you for help all the time)
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: A change of management may be the only way out

Wellington Management.summary: Great place to park a career
Wellington Management.pros: Flexible WLB, wonderful people, generous benefits and profit share
Wellington Management.cons: Training at the junior level is sparse and not very effective, need to find your own way, not a ton of development opportunities unless you are on the right team with the right people.  Politics are clandestine (as if they don't exist, but they do).

Wellington Management.pros: Great culture- everyone gets along well and we truly feel like friends. Good work life balance- an 8 hour workday is respected and taking truly unplugged time off is the norm. Good healthcare benefits
Wellington Management.cons:
I unfortunately had to leave Wellington due to low pay. It is truly a shame because I loved working there, but with the current cost of living, I needed to make more to get ahead. I had been hanging on because of the three days in office flexibility, but once they took that away and required us to come in four days a week, I started making exit plans as most 4 day in office jobs in this industry pay at least 50-75% more than Wellington. 

When I joined Wellington several years ago, I was told that the job stability was excellent and there were never layoffs. Unfortunately, this proved to not be true as there were at least 3 separate instances of layoffs during my time at the firm. 

Finally, the firm talks about meritocracy and transparency, but neither of those things are actually true in practice. The people who are promoted are the ones who present the most obedient image, and performance is not taken into consideration. As far as transparency goes, every message from upper management in the past 2 or so years was complete gibberish.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: If you are going to pay substandard wages while requiring above average attendance, what employees do you think you will retain?

Wellington Management.summary: A Good company To work for
Wellington Management.pros: has a strong reputation and gives you exposure to large scale investment operations and talented teams
Wellington Management.cons: heavy deadlines and strict compliance rules

Wellington Management.pros:
The firm still holds a strong reputation within the industry, especially beyond the Boston area (it’s a small world).

On an individual level, there are many talented and intelligent people. If you can afford to keep your head in the sand and just focus on your daily tasks, ignoring politics and gossip, or if you don't care about personal growth and promotions, you still can find an intellectually stimulating environment. 

Annual profit sharing of 15% of total comp deposited into 401k is a nice perk not offered by many.
Wellington Management.cons:
The firm is currently operated more like an unprofessional family business. There’s a clear reason why they rarely hire external candidates into truly meaningful senior executive roles: doing so would risk exposing the deep-rooted lack of professionalism and lack of direction that have existed for at least a decade. It’s astonishing that a company built on scrutinizing other companies as investments can itself be run with such poor governance and a glaring absence of accountability for poor decisions and mismanagement.
Mid-level managers largely survive by managing up and, more often than not, act as enforcers rather than true leaders. Many resemble small-time mafia bosses, prioritizing obedience and loyalty over merit and capability. What was once marketed as a “great culture” has devolved into a network of cliques and inner circles. If you’re not aligning yourself with the right people, you’ll likely end up marginalized—regardless of your achievements, skills or potential.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: It’s clear they couldn’t care less about advice. If they had even a trace of introspection or conscience, they would have quit—or committed harakiri—long ago.

Wellington Management.pros:
Friendly co-workers
Good compensation
Ownership of work/projects
Wellington Management.cons: Teams can be scattered between remote workers which makes it difficult to contact some team members

Wellington Management.pros: an entry way into the industry
Wellington Management.cons: wansnt as big on culture and didnt feel appreciated by people

Wellington Management.pros:
decent pay 
great people to work with
Wellington Management.cons:
no progression 
management don't know what they're doing

Wellington Management.pros:
I think the company is still great despite performance headwinds in recent years leading to several rounds of layoffs.

Still maintains a very humanistic approach to engagement with employees.
Wellington Management.cons: Some very incompetent people in leadership finally being weeded out.

Wellington Management.pros: kind team, environment, nice office
Wellington Management.cons: nothing comes to mind tbh

Wellington Management.pros: Great culture, provides excellent mentorship and ability to learn.
Wellington Management.cons: Needs better transparency on the future of the company.

Wellington Management.pros: Generally speaking I find most people to be kind, collegial.
Wellington Management.cons: A lot of bureaucracy and politics. Lot of promotion / opportunity for upward mobility determined by who you have in your corner. Excluding that cultural rot, big secular pressures on the business

Wellington Management.pros: The firm has an incredible culture.
Wellington Management.cons: While the culture is great, the comp is lower than competitors.

Wellington Management.pros: Bunch of really smart colleagues to work with
Wellington Management.cons: I’m reporting into my manager who is 5 years my Junior but has spent his entire 10 year career at Welington while i bring in 1.5 decades of experience at a couple of storied banks but that counts for nothing at Wellington since i didn’t come through the ranks here.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: None. This is a sinking ship

Wellington Management.pros: Great place, smart people working there and everyone is inviting
Wellington Management.cons: I have no problems here

Wellington Management.pros: free coffee and snacks in office
Wellington Management.cons: culture has gone downhill in recent years

Wellington Management.summary: Wellington seems to have lost its way.
Wellington Management.pros: Profitable company that is looking to expand its product offerings.  It is not staying still and hoping the industry doesn't change.
Wellington Management.cons: The firm insists it is profitable and it looking to focus the business on newer more profitable lines of business.  But, it looks like they are randomly laying off senior people, who most likely are the costliest.   This is the BCG playbook.  Lay off the expensive people and hire new, cheaper people.  Along the way, the culture is changed if not lost. This is exactly what has been happening -- more politics less productivity.  Its a shame.

Wellington Management.summary: On its way down- are they preparing to sell themselves?
Wellington Management.pros: Three years of layoffs means they are VERY  LEAN, so you can learn a lot, you have to!
Wellington Management.cons: Layoffs three years in a row. Are they getting ready to sell themselves? Who knows. Unless you are an investor of some sexy new alt, don’t apply, you won’t matter to them.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: Stop trying to cut everything, people DO NOT have to stay. Change your partnership agreement to save money for operations instead of continuing to take it from your people. Look closely at BCG’s clients….three years out they are unwinding the things that were detrimental to their companies. Pay more attention to the fact that you are DESTROYING the culture you claim to be so proud of. No I wasn’t laid off, so this isn’t retribution…..it’s really sad to see how far the company has fallen. BCG is not the expert about Wellington, YOU ARE. Why are you letting 20 something’s ruin what you’ve created.

Wellington Management.pros:
Good people
Generally interesting work
Wellington Management.cons: No longer like it used to be

Wellington Management.summary: Used to be a great place to work
Wellington Management.pros:
Working with some of the smartest people around, most of whom really want to do a good job as well as help out their colleagues.

Despite a couple down years, compensation is still higher than peers for many roles. All cash model - no deferred. 401K contribution is outstanding.
Wellington Management.cons:
Management is a dumpster fire the last 2 years. Incapable of coherent communication - e.g. highly anticipated firm-wide update that's something like 2 pages long and says virtually nothing new. CEO cannot speak in large group settings to save her life. About 5 people actually run the show now and anyone who challenges or raises concerns is marginalized.

Added way too many positions in 2022 leading to only the 2nd RIF in the company's history in 2023 and almost certainly another one before the end of 2024. No one feels secure in their job anymore.

They've got some good ideas on how to return the company to growth, but they seem to forget they need to communicate these things to their employees. Instead, they say nothing or talk in riddles and then can't understand why morale is low and no one buys into their vision for the future.

Your next opportunity will be decided by a bunch of people in a room who don't know much about you. Opportunity to control your destiny is not what it used to be.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: You want to transform your company? Try actually talking to the people who work there to bring them on the journey. Hearts and minds - leadership 101.

Wellington Management.summary: Don’t bother if you’re not on the Investment platform
Wellington Management.pros: Most of the people care about the work and there are a few select people working to maintain what was good about the culture.
Wellington Management.cons: Little to no respect for those outside of the Investment platform. I’d even go so far as to say that leadership has gone out of their way to disrespect those on the ground doing the work that enables investors to do their jobs.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: Put leaders in place that actually lead. They’ve created a culture where everyone is only concerned about themselves, which is going to be really difficult to reverse.

Wellington Management.pros:
Innovative
Best talent pool
Good salary and benefits
Wellington Management.cons:
Toxic middle management
Doers are not rewarded but the presenters/talkers are

Wellington Management.pros: profit share, stretch assignments, collegial culture and teams
Wellington Management.cons: limited management professional development opportunity

Wellington Management.summary: Decent place but going through changes
Wellington Management.pros: Great group of people to work with who are very talented; opportunity to take on new projects and own space during period of change
Wellington Management.cons: Pay is below industry standard; culture has changed over the last few years and lost a lot of what used to make it great; work life balance is not what it once was.

Wellington Management.pros: Reputable company with hard working individuals
Wellington Management.cons: Lots of changes with little warning

Wellington Management.pros:
Great place to work.
Good work life balance
Wellington Management.cons: commute is the only issue soemtimes.

Wellington Management.pros: Lean firm with impactful roles
Wellington Management.cons: poor office culture with disconnected teams

Wellington Management.pros: Talented and dedicated individuals who actively continue to recollect and foster a strong, collaborative work culture.
Wellington Management.cons: diminishing team-oriented culture at the management level, an emphasis on quantity over the quality of deliverables, incoherent and uninformative communication from management, inconsistency and ineffectiveness in senior leadership messaging, and a disconnect between stated intentions and actual actions.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management:
Sudden layoffs without notice damage trust and morale. Employees deserve honest, upfront communication about the company’s financial and strategic challenges. A consulting firm’s input is not a justification to avoid taking responsibility for internal decisions.

Align talk with Actions. Leadership must bridge the gap between what is said and what is done. Promises of stability and commitment to employees cannot coexist with abrupt, unannounced layoffs. Consistency is critical for credibility.

Outsourcing critical decisions to consultant firm suggests a lack of confidence in internal leadership capabilities. Invest in fostering a strong, accountable leadership team that can navigate challenges without external dependence.

Wellington Management.pros: Great Culture and benefits included
Wellington Management.cons: RTO is rough requires 4 days in office

Wellington Management.pros: Though they are starting to feel few and far between, there are some incredibly smart and really kind people here.
Wellington Management.cons:
I can’t add more than what people have already written because it is ALL true. You will be asked to work multiple positions and will not be fairly compensated for it, nor is this disclosed during the interview process. Trust nobody because everyone is scared for their jobs and will backstab to either get ahead or keep their jobs. Management can easily change the narrative about you to appease their own agenda. This has not happened before at other firms I’ve encountered.

Lastly, and most importantly, only come here if you’re white.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: Get rid of ALL of your current management. The existing layers have been there too long, and they didn’t get there through merit.

Wellington Management.summary: Greatly enjoyed my career there, not without its faults though
Wellington Management.pros:
The infrastructure team I worked with was some of the best I’ve had the pleasure of being a part of.

I was given the opportunity to train and grow in my technical skills.

A lot of interesting technology to maintain and support

I was given the opportunity to expand my comfort zone of work once I asked for it
Wellington Management.cons:
Some of the cons weren’t entirely their fault. A lot of teams needed more support to do the workload they had been building up, but after layoffs and hiring freezes that same amount of work was left to a lower number of people. Management would always agree that more support was needed but unfortunately it was impossible to get the approvals for a new hire.

If you connect yourself with your work you need to be ready to be stressed a bit with the global culture. Having offices in Singapore, Boston, and London often means you will be getting emails and messages off your core hours and it can feel like it never stops. You need to be prepared to draw a line if that is something you care about.

Wellington Management.pros: Good work life balance and recommend others too
Wellington Management.cons: Too many reorgs in recent days

Wellington Management.summary: Once great firm with declining culture
Wellington Management.pros: Work with incredibly smart, compassionate, and collaborative peeple. Firm always lived by a truly client, firm self ethos that has begun to go away.
Wellington Management.cons: Culture is a precious commodity. There has been a gradual decline of the client-first culture and too much focus on pushing flavor-of-the-month products irrespective of client needs. The rapid push into alts and privates without the supporting infrastructure (or talent) has come at a cost. Many great client and infrastrucure support folks have been terminated or managed out.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: Better start to pay the good people who reman; lots of resumes flooding the market. Expect more departurtes post bonus time. Investors do not generally make good CEOs.

Wellington Management.summary: Case study on how to ruin a great company
Wellington Management.pros: Collaborative. If you’re lucky, you might get to work with one of the few super smart investors and learn from them .
Wellington Management.cons:
1. Lack of Meritocracy: Leadership decisions often seem disconnected from true performance and talent. Individuals who rise to the top are not necessarily those best suited to manage money, which is evident in the firm’s subpar performance.
	2.	Toxic Culture: Recent layoffs have worsened an already tense environment. The company now operates with a survivalist mentality, characterized by backstabbing and political maneuvering. This creates a culture of mistrust among employees.
	3.	Client Neglect: The focus has shifted from prioritizing client needs to self-preservation. This short-term, self-serving attitude undermines the firm’s long-term success and is reflected in its performance.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management:
Foster a true meritocracy by aligning leadership roles with capability and performance.
	•	Focus on rebuilding trust among employees by addressing the political culture and promoting collaboration.
	•	Reorient the firm’s priorities back toward client outcomes, as this will ultimately drive sustainable success.

Wellington Management.summary: Prestigious company that has been losing its luster
Wellington Management.pros: Wellington historically has hired some of the smartest and motivated individuals in combination with ones that fit into their company culture that has created a very successful workforce. Employees are treated well with lots of benefits and beautiful offices. The company uses a lot of the latest cutting edge technology and products.
Wellington Management.cons: Wellington used to pride itself in its fraternal and prestigious culture. After the hiring surge during covid this culture was heavily eroded, mixed with the new CEO Jean making poor decisions that have steadily been dragging the company down. Many of the heavy hitter investors and technology leaders have since left the company.

Wellington Management.pros: Good work environment with friendly coworkers
Wellington Management.cons: Lunch is no longer free and they shrink the sandwich size

Wellington Management.pros: Used to be a great company with a stellar reputation and lots of career growth opportunities. Currently there are no pros.
Wellington Management.cons: Since the new leadership team took over, Wellington has fallen off of a cliff. The amazing culture they constantly tout is completely dead and everyone is desperate to leave before they go down with the ship. Leadership plays favorites, and allows toxic managers to continue their horrible behavior towards associates. If it gets bad enough, they just transfer the abusive managers to a different group to reset. Many junior level employees have tried raising issues, but they are swept under the rug and then threatened with termination if they don't fall in line. Middle managers disguise the horrible treatment of employees by gaslighting them and telling them it's their performance that is the issue, not the company itself. Consider this company if you like being verbally abused and don't enjoy job security.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: Get rid of the people who are destroying your culture and listen to your employees. If you don't curb your selfish behavior and treat every employee with respect, you'll soon find that you have no one left to work with.

Wellington Management.pros: Company culture is pretty nice
Wellington Management.cons: Boast about flexibility while they actively take it away. Layoffs happening more frequently. Little to no transparency. Pay sucks the longer you stay. No real employee retention

Wellington Management.pros: Contrary to what a lot of other major Boston asset management firms claim. Wellington actually has or should I say had, a very unique and empowering culture. More BIPOC work at Wellington Management in Boston than. Any other similar sized asset management firms in the city. There was a time in the last 3 years, the firm was seriously moving in great direction.
Wellington Management.cons: Wellington's financial situation has made it impossible to stay there. Every week there's a withdrawing partner. On top of the 1 - 4 regular full-time employees departing as well. Almost all with the same story, "I love(ed) it here, I wish I could stay." However nobody is getting counter offers. In fact since the layoffs in May of 2023, it's just been a revolving door of good people leaving.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: Make a decision! Either you're on pace to be one of the most diverse and inclusive firms in Boston with a commitment to hiring BIPOC, and other ethnic groups of difference. Or revert to the previous ways of the Ole boys club etc. stuff. It's time to make a decision. CEO is great or can be great, if she's allowed to make the changes she very much seems like she wants to make. Senior leadership needs more BIPOC, and please stop with the attack on hybrid working. The pandemic changed the world.

Wellington Management.pros: Learning curve of new technologies, Freedom to express views, No micro management, work culture
Wellington Management.cons: Not thinking of any cons

Wellington Management.pros: People here take pride in their work and are lovely to work with, lots of opportunities to learn outside of your role, lots of flexibility in your work schedule.
Wellington Management.cons: The firm seems to be confused where it is headed with it's products, they have done so many reorgs and layoffs that it's created a stressful environment. The work life balance has also gotten worse with the shrinking workforce but pay hasn't been increased.

Wellington Management.pros: Mostly smart people trying to do good work for clients
Wellington Management.cons:
It's almost impressive how senior leadership has torpedoed the once-great culture and reputation of a ~100 year firm in under two years. What used to be an incredible shop full of the sharpest and kindest in the business has been upended in the blink of an eye. Mass layoffs, poor business results, and incompetent leadership teams have taken the life out of Wellington. Morale is in the gutter. Performing countless reorgs with no clear vision doesn't help sentiment. 

Many have already left and countless more privately discuss wanting to leave. This current climate is not sustainable and word is getting out.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: Talk plainly and earnestly to people at all levels of the firm. Admit there is a problem and try to restore the days of leaders being excellent coaches and investors. The ingredients are still there but most current leadership teams are woefully out of touch. Current CEO needs to step down as a start.

Wellington Management.summary: Good Place Not for Early Career
Wellington Management.pros: Great benefits, particularly 401k matching and profit sharing
Wellington Management.cons: Slow progression and tough to advance career as new hire

Wellington Management.pros: Pretty relaxed environment. Don't have too much workload
Wellington Management.cons: Pay is not the best compared to other SWE jobs in Boston.

Wellington Management.pros: You will be pushed in a safe, welcoming environment. Honestly the best working environment that you can ask for
Wellington Management.cons: They took away free lunch? I mean I'm really struggling to come up with a bad thing to say, but on everything that matters they are a fantastic company.

Wellington Management.summary: Not a great place to work - avoid
Wellington Management.pros: The people are really nice and I’ve met some awesome friends.
Wellington Management.cons: The past few years at Wellington post-COVID have been particularly uneasy and unsettling for employees. Since the layoffs in 2023, the atmosphere has changed, with ongoing budget cuts and low morale. The office is quiet, with little interaction, as many people seem eager to move to different companies. There’s a constant feeling of instability, with frequent resignations or terminations, and the recent voluntary leave package led to over 100 departures. Rumors of another layoff before the new year are circulating, which wouldn’t be surprising given the company’s unsustainable spending on new office spaces. Consider joining Wellington only if you're prepared for instability and the risk of job loss.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: Listen to your employees—morale is low, and the lack of communication is alarming. It’s starting to feel like senior management is intentionally neglecting concerns, hoping people leave on their own to reduce headcount without more layoffs. You need to do better. Other companies are aware of the situation, and your reputation is suffering.

Wellington Management.pros: People are generally smart and kind. Pay is OK.
Wellington Management.cons: The firm is going downhill and there is no sign it can recover. In certain department (and it could be a Wellington culture across departments) the culture is toxic. Under the leadership, people pretend to work very hard and are under big presure. But at the end of the day, nothing is delivered or the delivered work is not important to the firm at all. The whole purpose of the work is to satisfy the grandiose achievements and make some look good. Hence no doubt there is micromanagement and manager can breath down your neck everyday.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: Have true longer term vision. Being Innovative and entrepreneurial. willingness to take risk. You have smart talent but you need to organize smartly to appreciate their skills.

Wellington Management.pros: Its a collaborative environment, with plenty of mentorship within the firm
Wellington Management.cons: Theres a lack of real training and development

Wellington Management.pros: Large firm, opportunities for mobility, pay structure
Wellington Management.cons: Mgmt can be difficult at times

Wellington Management.pros: The people are the best. They really care about doing a good job and are willing to help each other when needed.
Wellington Management.cons: Senior management has lost touch with the culture of the firm through repeated re-orgs over the last few years. Pay is way down as well due in part to enormous pay guarantees given to new employees with private equity experience. This push into private equity is creating a lot of resentment among legacy employees given bonuses are going down despite markets being up. They are also laying off employees through numerous waves, which is killing morale.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: Replace senior management.

Wellington Management.pros: Great place to get exposure to asset management. Very good culture
Wellington Management.cons: None I can think of

Wellington Management.summary: Going downhill with new CEO & cut throat culture
Wellington Management.pros: Benefits are good - Insurance is better than most firms, Profit Sharing is one of the best, Cutting Edge products and technology, Most people are smarter than the average Joe.
Wellington Management.cons: The company used to pride on it's culture but with industry pressure and some bad investment decisions, expensive hiring and unnecessary expenses, the culture has gone down hill. The morale is low and many people are looking to leave. The new CEO is to be blamed for a lot of this as the company also went through it's first round of layoffs ever. Promotions are impossible unless you are amongst the top 2% or a minority that will help their diversity numbers look good (yes, women & people of color/LGBT+ have a good chance). Managers have been asked to fake reviews to make a PIP list and be prepared for additional layoffs, even if the employee is meeting expectations. Trading and Investment teams are obviously more valuable. The Infrastructure group is run poorly as they have very smart people who are not treated unfairly. Some of them are the smartest in the firm but don't get promoted (or mentored) since management is biased. If you don't get promoted every 4-5 years, you are labeled as someone who will never be promoted again (time for you to leave)!
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: CEO LT needs to be more transparent (stop all of the secretive operations). Also, Investech is run differently than the rest of the firm.. different culture where you  are not encouraged to speak up. If you do, you will get labeled and lose any promotion opportunities.

Wellington Management.summary: Not the worst in Finance but culture no longer exists
Wellington Management.pros: Very smart and high integrity people across departments. Benefits are decent with profit sharing and bonus (as long as the firm is having a good year). Now business casual (unless you're meeting with clients) post-COVID. Work/life balance can be decent if you have a good manager (there are definitely good managers, but its probably 50/50 across functions).
Wellington Management.cons: Where do I start. Culture is a cult and no longer exists - if you are looking to work here and culture is the deciding factor, please reconsider. On the day to day, the individuals I worked with across departments were great and tried to perpetuate the culture where they can but unfortunately senior leadership is undermining any remaining shred of the "Wellington Culture." Mismanagement has lead to all-time low in morale and the recent RIF (layoffs) will be the final nail in the coffin for those of us left. Player/coach management model doesn't work and there are too many senior department heads who play the game to be promoted vs. having the correct skills to lead/positively change departments. If you are not an investor or a salesperson, you'll be ignored and underpaid.
Wellington Management.advice_to_management: Please consider stepping down or adding other managing partners to the line up; someone needs to be held accountable for the RIF while our competitors are hiring.

State Street.summary: Stable company with good work-life balance

State Street.pros:
Some teams have talented individual contributors who genuinely care about doing good work,

There seems to be a decent mobility program for moving across departments, but moving upwards is difficult.

Training is encouraged.
State Street.cons:
Leadership is deeply political, with constant castle-building across teams that compete instead of collaborate. Leaders protect their own empires rather than improving outcomes, which creates silos, conflict, and endless turf wars. High turnover at the top means priorities shift every few months, leaving teams scrambling to realign or fight over work. Offshore dependency creates huge gaps in communication and accountability for security functions that require speed and context. Career advancement is nearly impossible unless you’re aligned with the right political faction, regardless of merit or contribution. The culture rewards survival, not excellence. 

Advertised benefits are also not reliably given. Reimbursements and perks often come with hidden technicalities, and you can spend weeks chasing approvals only to be denied over small procedural details.
State Street.advice_to_management: Jump ship

State Street.pros: Clear career path for new employees, competent co-workers.
State Street.cons: Jobs offshored, constantly changing leadership.

State Street.pros:
Strong Brand and Global Presence: State Street is a well-established leader in asset servicing and custody. Working here gives you exposure to global markets and a wide array of institutional clients.

Job Stability: This is not a “boom and bust” firm. For someone looking for a stable career path, especially in back-office or operational roles, State Street offers a secure foundation.

Work-Life Balance: Depending on your team, there is often a good balance between workload and personal time. Hybrid and remote work options are available in many roles.

Learning Opportunities: There are plenty of internal resources and e-learning tools (via Skillsoft and LinkedIn Learning), and some teams offer support for industry certifications like CFA or CPA.

Diversity and Inclusion: The company has made meaningful strides in DEI over the past few years, with employee resource groups and inclusive hiring practices improving steadily.
State Street.cons:
Slow Career Advancement: Promotions and compensation increases tend to lag compared to competitors. Many employees feel stuck at the Associate or AVP level for years.

Bureaucracy and Red Tape: As a legacy financial institution, decision-making can be painfully slow. Processes are often outdated, and innovation is hampered by internal politics.

Underwhelming Pay: Salaries and bonuses are generally below industry average. Raises are modest, and performance recognition is inconsistent.

High Turnover in Some Teams: Particularly in operations-heavy departments, there is high attrition, which puts pressure on remaining staff.

Tech and Automation Challenges: While the company talks a lot about digital transformation, many systems are still legacy and patchworked together, which creates inefficiencies and manual work.

State Street.pros: Good People, nice locations, etc.
State Street.cons: Pay did not keep pace with inflation.

State Street.summary: Don’t apply unless you want to be up at midnight every night reserving desks
State Street.pros: None at all anymore since taking away work from home.
State Street.cons:
Basically, you have to be up at midnight every night in order to book a desk, if you are not able to book a desk, you will end up losing your job since you have to be in the office four days a week. Desks are not assigned anymore.
Very, very low pay, basically no bonuses at all. Expected to work extremely long hours and after working long hours getting back up during the night to book a desk, I’m glad upper management thinks that this is a great idea.
State Street.advice_to_management: Think about making people get up in the middle of the night to book a desk, we can’t even have the decency at this company to assign a desk to everybody. This is unbelievable, what kind of company makes their employees get up at midnight just to be able to sit in the office.

State Street.pros:
-Big name company on your resume. If you're a woman, from Ireland and/or close buddies with anyone from the Ireland SOC office...you will do very well here. You will get promoted often, even if your skills/contributions doesn't justify the promotion(s). And on top of that, you can get SANS vouchers easily as well.

-If you don't fullfill the above requirements, do your time here and move on elsewhere.
State Street.cons:
-If you're based in America, don't expect much support from the Ireland side of the SOC. Favoritism is very apparent in the SOC for non-Americans. Exceptions include: if an American is virtually dating someone from Ireland.
 
-Promotions will tend to be received by the folk from Ireland due to major cybersecurity stakeholders being mostly based out of Kilkenny.
State Street.advice_to_management: None since feedback will fall on deaf ears.

State Street.summary: great company to retire if you are in the right team
State Street.pros: opportunities to bring in new technology
State Street.cons:
Tech staff are like second class citizens
Shame culture and toxic upper management
0 innovation
State Street.advice_to_management:
Eliminate the shame/fear culture: Adopt a “blameless postmortem” practice for technology and business incidents. Focus on learning, not punishment.

Celebrate experiments: Highlight small wins where teams tried something new—even if imperfect. This builds tolerance for learning and reduces fear of failure.

Leadership modeling: Executives need to explicitly share their own failures and lessons to normalize experimentation.
Reduce contractor over-reliance: Transition key roles to permanent employees to retain institutional knowledge, loyalty, and innovation ownership. Contractors should fill short-term skill gaps, not form the backbone of critical teams.

Management accountability: Include leadership behavior as part of performance reviews and tie incentives to people metrics (attrition, engagement, innovation adoption).

State Street.cons: Due to policy it seemed no matter how hard people worked there was only so much to give out in raises and bonus so many were given nothing or all given practical nothing toward the last years I was there.

State Street.summary: "Well-Rounded Business Analyst with Strong Technical Edge and Global Experience"
State Street.pros:
Solid Blend of Business & Technical Skills:
You effectively bridge the gap between business and tech, with experience in process mapping, stakeholder communication, as well as hands-on tools like SQL, Python, Tableau, Power BI, and cloud platforms (AWS, GCP, Azure).

Strong Domain Exposure:
Experience in both Finance and SaaS domains makes your profile attractive to a wide range of employers.

Clear Impact & Metrics:
You’ve quantified your achievements well — like “30% increase in processing speed,” “95% client satisfaction,” “$100K in savings,” etc., which gives credibility to your impact.

Global Work Experience:
Experience working both in the U.S. (State Street) and India (Groovy Web) showcases adaptability and a global mindset.

Versatile Tool Stack:
Proficient in modern and in-demand tools (Jira, Confluence, Snowflake, Informatica, SharePoint, Power BI, Tableau) — makes you versatile across different teams and projects.

Strong Documentation & UAT Skills:
Clear mention of BRDs, FRDs, RTMs, SRS, UAT — valuable for roles requiring end-to-end SDLC involvement.
State Street.cons:
Formatting Consistency & Readability:
The original text could benefit from more consistent formatting (spacing, bullet alignment, section headings) to improve readability at first glance — though that’s easily fixable.

Missing LinkedIn URL:
You mention LinkedIn but don’t provide the actual link — recruiters often want to check your profile quickly.

Education Timeline Confusion:
The Master’s degree is listed as Sep 2024, which is in the future. This needs clarification: is it your graduation date? If so, label it as “Expected Sep 2024.”

No Certifications Mentioned:
If you have any certifications (like CBAP, PMI-PBA, AWS Certified, or Tableau/Power BI certs), adding them would boost your credibility further.

No Mention of Agile Artifacts (like User Stories, Epics, Backlog Grooming):
Since you mention Agile experience, showcasing familiarity with core Agile artifacts would add more weight.

State Street.pros:
Strong object-oriented structure that helps build maintainable and reusable code.

Excellent for scalable, enterprise-grade applications and microservices.

Rich ecosystem with frameworks like Spring Boot and libraries for testing, security, and database interaction.

Cross-platform support and robust performance in multi-threaded environments.
State Street.cons:
Dynamic typing can lead to runtime errors and harder debugging in large projects.

Browser inconsistencies and fragmented ecosystem sometimes complicate development.

Performance may not match compiled languages for CPU-intensive tasks.

Rapidly changing frameworks and libraries require continuous learning to stay updated.

Brutal re-org in play and some really valuable employees on the receiving end.
Laptops and VDI/MVW are terribly slow and kill productivity.
State Street.advice_to_management:
Know your company better and make grounded decisions. Marketing is important but so are the foundations ! Don't reward incompetence hidden under layers of excel sheets
Get on the AI bandwagon, by all means. But remember by sorting out laptops and VDI/MVW - you can unlock 50% productivity gain in your technology teams. In absence, copilot will be just another thing they struggle to use !

State Street.summary: House of cards politics and lack of trust
State Street.pros: There were many advantages when Charles River Development operated as an autonomous organization, even though it was owned by State Street. Better pay than similar firms in Boston, and great talent to work with, but none of that is true anymore. Please check the cons.
State Street.cons: This place is like a house of cards. The company is full of politics. The management from State Street took over Charles River leadership and brought the dirty politics. Everything you hear or see is just a smoke screen. If you are honest, committed to your work, and want to build a great product for State Street customers, you will likely face backstabbing and be let go. State Street laid off 20-50-100 talented individuals who had given decades of their careers and lives to the company on whim, not once or twice, but every few months. There were four layoff rounds in 2025 alone, and more seem to be coming. The irony is that the team bringing in a good amount of revenue is penalized to save those who make no real contribution. Consulting companies like Galatia and Deloitte, among others, receive better treatment than hardworking employees with product and industry knowledge. Not sure if someone is getting a kickback from these consulting firms, and be ready to lose your job to consultants any time unless you are good at faking your work and keeping management happy with your hollow talks. Seriously, if you have family or are trying to build a real career, this is not a place for you. Don't get fooled by the pay package. If you don't trust this review, just ask anyone working there, except those involved in the politics.
State Street.advice_to_management: You may be getting cheated by a few people in the middle. Please investigate to determine why good people are being unfairly targeted. What you see and hear may not be the true story. Do you want to deceive your loyal customers by concealing real problems in the product design and architecture, or acknowledge those issues and genuinely attempt to resolve them? Especially check the relationship between some high-ranking individuals and consulting firms that receive large payments. Above all, please strive to create an atmosphere where employees feel free to report problems with leadership without fear of retribution or retaliation. Creating a multitude of training sessions is not enough. Do you really have a culture of listening?

State Street.pros: Culture: it’s seldom pretty but we get the job done. Truly toxic people don’t last. Honesty in words and actions from managing directors and under. Less candor from above.
State Street.cons: $ € £: Overworked and underpaid. Always promoting how do right by women and minorities yet always sited and fined for pay inequity. Even cis-gendered heterosexual fall behind if you stay too long. 20+ years of continuous service is really no service to your personal bottom line nor the bank’s for that matter. Do a sprint with a client or vendor to learn more then come back with experience that commands market pay and a higher bank title.
State Street.advice_to_management: Every 4-5 years there’s a cull. It’s time to buy out the older intransigent guard executive- and senior-VPs, MDs and VPs. Alpha was a genius stroke. Don’t let AI and DLT make it and the bank history.

State Street.pros: It’s a solid place to get your foot in the door if you’re early in your finance or accounting career. You get exposure to big-name clients and complex fund structures, which definitely builds your technical skills. The name carries weight on a resume. Depending on your team, the work-life balance isn’t bad either.
State Street.cons: The pay is honestly pretty low for the amount of work and responsibility. Raises are minimal, and bonuses are either small or nonexistent. It can feel like you’re doing a lot without really being compensated fairly, and promotions move slowly unless you really advocate for yourself. A good place to learn, but not somewhere I’d stay long-term unless the pay structure changes.

State Street.pros: Decent benefits for you and your family
State Street.cons: You only get promoted if you are friends with a boss
State Street.advice_to_management: Being fair to all employees will help retain the workforce

State Street.pros: The people at State Street were really kind and collaborative. If you can keep up with a fast-paced environment, this is a good place for you.
State Street.cons: The fast pace can be difficult if you are unprepared, like any major company.

State Street.pros: Offers good exposure to complex private equity structures and new deals. Big company so roles are departmental. Provides standard health benefits and a 401(k) plan with company matching.
State Street.cons: Workload spikes noticeably during quarter-end and audit season, especially on understaffed teams. Compensation and bonuses are not competitive with industry standards, and the culture can feel impersonal, with limited acknowledgment of individual effort due to the size and structure of the organization.

State Street.cons: People are resistant to change and adopt newer ideas

State Street.pros: Awesome people, wlb, environment, and office!
State Street.cons: The lunches in the cafeteria were expensive.

State Street.pros: It is a good place to learn when you're fresh out of college.
State Street.cons: In office mandates, horrible pay, senior managers keep increasing their compensation significantly annually while majority of employees get no pay increase or very little increase annually, it is difficult to advance unless a higher level position opens up, as promotions without open positions is not allowed, regardless of how are you work. There is no work life balance. Work is 8-10 hours per day, commute varies but many commute over an hour each direction.
State Street.advice_to_management: get rid of the toxic atmosphere and in office mandates. let the managers manage their own teams. If an AWA works best for certain team members because they are more productive not in the office, allow managers to make the call, let them hold the responsibility for their teams and their productivity. We are loosing too many knowledgeable and key employees.

State Street.pros: Good Company to work with
State Street.cons: Pay is very less comparative to other companies at that level

State Street.summary: Financial Services Professional at State Street Corporation  Delivering Excellence in Global Custody, Asset Servicing

State Street.cons: Poor Work life balance and management was not well managed.

State Street.summary: 3 days back in office after hired remotely
State Street.pros: Flexible working hours, was able to work remote for 3 years, staff is friendly, good starting pay
State Street.cons: They hired me remotely 3 years ago and then told me recently to back to office 3 days a week.
State Street.advice_to_management: Stop lying to your employees and say they are full remote and then change it. You will be hearing from my lawyer. They have all the proof of my hiring terms.

State Street.pros: Great work-life balance, great people, great teams.
State Street.cons: Various offices so sometimes there is a lot of commuting.

State Street.cons: Hard to schedule meetings, little intern interaction
